explanation:
To solve \(x^2 - x - 6 \geq 0\), factor the quadratic: \((x - 3)(x + 2) \geq 0\). The parabola opens upward, so the inequality holds when \(x \leq -2\) (left of the first root) or \(x \geq 3\) (right of the second root), written as a union: \(\{x \leq -2\} \cup \{x \geq 3\}\).

The student incorrectly wrote \(\{-2 \geq x \geq 3\}\), which implies \(x\) simultaneously satisfies \(-2 \geq x\) and \(x \geq 3\)—an impossibility. This error stems from misusing a two-tailed inequality to connect disjoint intervals. The student treated the union of two separate regions as a single compound inequality, violating the syntax of inequality chains (which require a monotonic progression). This matches the misconception that two-tailed inequalities can arbitrarily place constants in the middle, rather than recognizing they must describe continuous ranges. Unlike confusion about union/intersection or direction symbols, the core flaw is invalidly compressing two distinct intervals into one expression.
